channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: Chinese-Linked Hackers Exploit Windows Flaw to Spy on Belgian and Hungarian Diplomats
item.description: A new UNC6384 campaign highlights the threat actor’s growing sophistication and geographic expansion

item.title: The MSP Cybersecurity Readiness Guide: Turning Security into Growth
item.description: MSPs are facing rising client expectations for strong cybersecurity and compliance outcomes, while threats grow more complex and regulatory demands evolve. Meanwhile, clients are increasingly seeking comprehensive protection without taking on the burden of managing security themselves. This shift represents a major growth opportunity. By delivering advanced cybersecurity and compliance
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Will AI Strengthen or Undermine Democracy?
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Facial Recognition Firm Clearview AI Hit with Criminal Complaint in Austria
item.description: Clearview AI faces a criminal complaint in Austria for allegedly ignoring EU data protection rulings

item.title: Cyber's Role in the Rapid Rise of Digital Authoritarianism
item.description: Dark Reading Confidential Episode 11: Enterprise cyber teams are in prime position to push back against our current &quot;Golden Age of Surveillance,&quot; according to our guests Ronald Deibert from Citizen Lab and David Greene from the EFF.
item.dc:creator: Dark Reading Staff

item.title: CISA and NSA Issue Urgent Guidance to Secure WSUS and Microsoft Exchange Servers
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and National Security Agency (NSA), along with international partners from Australia and Canada, have released guidance to harden on-premise Microsoft Exchange Server instances from potential exploitation. "By restricting administrative access, implementing multi-factor authentication, enforcing strict transport security
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Eclipse Foundation Revokes Leaked Open VSX Tokens Following Wiz Discovery
item.description: Eclipse Foundation, which maintains the open-source Open VSX project, said it has taken steps to revoke a small number of tokens that were leaked within Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extensions published in the marketplace. The action comes following a report from cloud security company Wiz earlier this month, which found several extensions from both Microsoft's VS Code Marketplace and Open VSX
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA Flags VMware Zero-Day Exploited by China-Linked Hackers in Active Attacks
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Thursday added a high-severity security flaw impacting Broadcom VMware Tools and VMware Aria Operations to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, following reports of active exploitation in the wild. The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-41244 (CVSS score: 7.8), which could be exploited by an attacker to attain
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: A New Security Layer for macOS Takes Aim at Admin Errors Before Hackers Do
item.description: A design firm is editing a new campaign video on a MacBook Pro. The creative director opens a collaboration app that quietly requests microphone and camera permissions. MacOS is supposed to flag that, but in this case, the checks are loose. The app gets access anyway. On another Mac in the same office, file sharing is enabled through an old protocol called SMB version one. It’s fast and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Salesforce Extortion Accelerates With New Leak Site | UpGuard
item.description: The hacker collective Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters has launched a new leak site threatening to release data stolen from Salesforce instances.

item.title: Zombie Projects Rise Again to Undermine Security
item.description: Companies left them for dead, but the remnants of old infrastructure and failed projects continue to haunt businesses' security teams.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: An 18-Year-Old Codebase Left Smart Buildings Wide Open
item.description: Researcher Gjoko Krstic’s &quot;Project Brainfog&quot; exposed hundreds of zero-day vulnerabilities in building-automation systems still running hospitals, schools, and offices worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Joan Goodchild

item.title: Critical Claroty Authentication Bypass Flaw Opened OT to Attack
item.description: CVE-2025-54603 gave attackers an opening to disrupt critical operational technology (OT) environments and critical infrastructure, plus steal data from them.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: LotL Attack Hides Malware in Windows Native AI Stack
item.description: Security programs trust AI data files, but they shouldn't: they can conceal malware more stealthily than most file types.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Request for Comments: PCI PTS HSM v5.0
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: Google's Built-In AI Defenses on Android Now Block 10 Billion Scam Messages a Month
item.description: Google on Thursday revealed that the scam defenses built into Android safeguard users around the world from more than 10 billion suspected malicious calls and messages every month. The tech giant also said it has blocked over 100 million suspicious numbers from using Rich Communication Services (RCS), an evolution of the SMS protocol, thereby preventing scams before they could even be sent. In
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Critical Flaws Found in Elementor King Addons Affect 10,000 Sites
item.description: The King Addons for Elementor plugin contains two flaws allowing unauthenticated file uploads and privilege escalation

item.title: Russian Ransomware Gangs Weaponize Open-Source AdaptixC2 for Advanced Attacks
item.description: The open-source command-and-control (C2) framework known as AdaptixC2 is being used by a growing number of threat actors, some of whom are related to Russian ransomware gangs. AdaptixC2 is an emerging extensible post-exploitation and adversarial emulation framework designed for penetration testing. While the server component is written in Golang, the GUI Client is written in C++ QT for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Threat Actors Utilize AdaptixC2 for Malicious Payload Delivery
item.description: Cybercriminals are abusing AdaptixC2, a legitimate emulation framework, in ransomware campaigns

item.title: New "Brash" Exploit Crashes Chromium Browsers Instantly with a Single Malicious URL
item.description: A severe vulnerability disclosed in Chromium's Blink rendering engine can be exploited to crash many Chromium-based browsers within a few seconds. Security researcher Jose Pino, who disclosed details of the flaw, has codenamed it Brash. "It allows any Chromium browser to collapse in 15-60 seconds by exploiting an architectural flaw in how certain DOM operations are managed," Pino said in a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cloud Outages Highlight the Need for Resilient, Secure Infrastructure Recovery
item.description: Two massive technical outages over the past year underscore the need for cybersecurity teams to consider how to recover safely from disruptions without creating new security risks.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: Shadow AI: One In Four Employees Use Unapproved AI Tools, Research Finds
item.description: Over a quarter of employees work with AI tools that had not been authorized by their company

item.title: The Death of the Security Checkbox: BAS Is the Power Behind Real Defense
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: The AI-Designed Bioweapon Arms Race
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Proton Claims 300 Million Records Compromised So Far This Year
item.description: A new dark web analysis reveals more than 300 million records have been breached in 2025 to date

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: DNS Poisoning Flaw, Supply-Chain Heist, Rust Malware Trick and New RATs Rising
item.description: The comfort zone in cybersecurity is gone. Attackers are scaling down, focusing tighter, and squeezing more value from fewer, high-impact targets. At the same time, defenders face growing blind spots &mdash; from spoofed messages to large-scale social engineering. This week&rsquo;s findings show how that shrinking margin of safety is redrawing the threat landscape. Here&rsquo;s what&rsquo;s
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: PhantomRaven Malware Found in 126 npm Packages Stealing GitHub Tokens From Devs
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have uncovered yet another active software supply chain attack campaign targeting the npm registry with over 100 malicious packages that can steal authentication tokens, CI/CD secrets, and GitHub credentials from developers' machines. The campaign has been codenamed PhantomRaven by Koi Security. The activity is assessed to have begun in August 2025, when the first
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Defense Contractor Boss Pleads Guilty to Selling Zero-Day Exploits to Russia
item.description: The former general manager of defense contractor Trenchant has admitted selling zero-days to Russian broker

item.title: Penetration Testing and Scanning Policy
item.description: <p>Security or network incidents can be prevented by proactively detecting potential threat opportunities. Customizable Document — Ready for use as-is or for edits. Enhance Your Security — This eight-page document covers preparation, remediation, and more. Expertly-Curated — Written by Scott Matteson through 16 hours of research, writing, and editing. This resource is available to download ...</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/resource-library/it-policy/penetration-testing-scanning/">Penetration Testing and Scanning Policy</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: Data Leak Outs Hacker Students of Iran's MOIS Training Academy
item.description: Ravin Academy, a school for the Iranian state hackers of tomorrow, has itself, ironically, been hacked.

item.title: Malicious NPM Packages Disguised With 'Invisible' Dependencies
item.description: In the &quot;PhantomRaven&quot; campaign, threat actors published 126 malicious npm packages that have flown under the radar, while collecting 86,000 downloads.

item.title: AI Search Tools Easily Fooled by Fake Content
item.description: New research shows AI crawlers like Perplexity, Atlas, and ChatGPT are surprisingly easy to fool.

item.title: Dentsu Subsidiary Breached, Employee Data Stolen
item.description: A subsidiary of Japanese marketing and PR giant Dentsu lost sensitive data to unidentified threat actors, the parent company said.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Microsoft Security Change for Azure VMs Creates Pitfalls
item.description: Firms using Azure infrastructure gained a reprieve from a security-focused switch that could have broken apps that relied on public Internet access.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Botnets Step Up Cloud Attacks Via Flaws, Misconfigurations
item.description: Infamous botnets like Mirai are exploiting Web-exposed assets such as PHP servers, IoT devices, and cloud gateways to gain control over systems and build strength.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Chrome to Make HTTPS Mandatory by Default in 2026
item.description: Google Chrome will enhance security with enforced HTTPS connections from version 154, set for release in October 2026

item.title: Experts Reports Sharp Increase in Automated Botnet Attacks Targeting PHP Servers and IoT Devices
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers are calling attention to a spike in automated attacks targeting PHP servers, IoT devices, and cloud gateways by various botnets such as Mirai, Gafgyt, and Mozi. "These automated campaigns exploit known CVE vulnerabilities and cloud misconfigurations to gain control over exposed systems and expand botnet networks," the Qualys Threat Research Unit (TRU) said in a report
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New AI-Targeted Cloaking Attack Tricks AI Crawlers Into Citing Fake Info as Verified Facts
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have flagged a new security issue in agentic web browsers like OpenAI ChatGPT Atlas that exposes underlying artificial intelligence (AI) models to context poisoning attacks. item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Npm Malware Uses Invisible Dependencies to Infect Dozens of Packages
item.description: The ongoing ‘PhantomRaven’ malicious campaign has infected 126 npm packages to date, representing 86,000 downloads

item.title: PHP Servers and IoT Devices Face Growing Cyber-Attack Risks
item.description: A rise in attacks on PHP servers, IoT devices and cloud gateways is linked to botnets exploiting flaws, according to new research published by Qualys

item.title: From Power Users to Protective Stewards: How to Tune Security Training for Specialized Employees
item.description: The best security training programs build strong security culture by focusing on high-risk groups, including developers, executives, and finance pros.
item.dc:creator: Ericka Chickowski, Contributing Writer

item.title: Discover Practical AI Tactics for GRC — Join the Free Expert Webinar
item.description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly transforming Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC). It's no longer a future concept—it's here, and it's already reshaping how teams operate. AI's capabilities are profound: it's speeding up audits, flagging critical risks faster, and drastically cutting down on time-consuming manual work. This leads to greater efficiency, higher accuracy, and a more
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Preparing for the Digital Battlefield of 2026: Ghost Identities, Poisoned Accounts, & AI Agent Havoc
item.description: BeyondTrust’s annual cybersecurity predictions point to a year where old defenses will fail quietly, and new attack vectors will surge. Introduction The next major breach won’t be a phished password. It will be the result of a massive, unmanaged identity debt. This debt takes many forms: it’s the “ghost” identity from a 2015 breach lurking in your IAM, the privilege sprawl from thousands of new
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Russian Hackers Target Ukrainian Organizations Using Stealthy Living-Off-the-Land Tactics
item.description: Organizations in Ukraine have been targeted by threat actors of Russian origin with an aim to siphon sensitive data and maintain persistent access to compromised networks. The activity, according to a new report from the Symantec and Carbon Black Threat Hunter Team, targeted a large business services organization for two months and a local government entity in the country for a week. The attacks
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New Atroposia RAT Surfaces on Dark Web
item.description: Atroposia is a newly discovered modular RAT that uses encrypted channels and advanced theft capabilities to target credentials and crypto wallets

item.title: Open Source “b3” Benchmark to Boost LLM Security for Agents
item.description: The backbone breaker benchmark (b3) has been launched to enhance the security of LLMs within AI agents

item.title: Lookalike Domain Attacks Explained | UpGuard
item.description: Learn about lookalike domain attacks, why they’re on the rise, and how to prevent them using automated monitoring and layered cybersecurity defenses.

item.title: 10 npm Packages Caught Stealing Developer Credentials on Windows, macOS, and Linux
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a set of 10 malicious npm packages that are designed to deliver an information stealer targeting Windows, Linux, and macOS systems. "The malware uses four layers of obfuscation to hide its payload, displays a fake CAPTCHA to appear legitimate, fingerprints victims by IP address, and downloads a 24MB PyInstaller-packaged information stealer that harvests
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Active Exploits Hit Dassault and XWiki — CISA Confirms Critical Flaws Under Attack
item.description:
Threat actors are actively exploiting multiple security flaws impacting Dassault Systèmes DELMIA Apriso and XWiki, according to alerts issued by the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and VulnCheck. The vulnerabilities are listed below -
CVE-2025-6204 (CVSS score: 8.0) - A code injection vulnerability in Dassault Systèmes DELMIA Apriso that could allow an attacker to
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cybersecurity Firms See Surge in AI-Powered Attacks Across Africa
item.description: Africa becomes a proving ground for AI-driven phishing, deepfakes, and impersonation, with attackers testing techniques against governments and enterprises.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: A CISO's Guide to the Business Risks of AI Development Platforms | UpGuard
item.description: This guide provides a strategic framework for understanding and mitigating the new wave of threats emerging from this AI-driven ecosystem.

item.title: AI-Generated Code Poses Security, Bloat Challenges
item.description: Development teams that fail to create processes around AI-generated code face more technical and security debt as vulnerabilities get replicated.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Aisuru Botnet Shifts from DDoS to Residential Proxies
item.description: Aisuru, the botnet responsible for a series of record-smashing distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks this year, recently was overhauled to support a more low-key, lucrative and sustainable business: Renting hundreds of thousands of infected Internet of Things (IoT) devices to proxy services that help cybercriminals anonymize their traffic. Experts says a glut of proxies from Aisuru and other sources is fueling large-scale data harvesting efforts tied to various artificial intelligence (AI) projects, helping content scrapers evade detection by routing their traffic through residential connections that appear to be regular Internet users.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: Why Risk Assessments Fail Stakeholders: Bridging the Gap | UpGuard
item.description: Learn how to prevent your risk assessment reports from stalling in stakeholder review by translating technical findings into actionable language.

item.title: The Do's & Don'ts of Writing Audit-Proof Risk Assessments | UpGuard
item.description: Are your third-party risk assessments built to pass audit examination? This practical guide reveals the do's and don'ts to ensure you pass with confidence.

item.title: Inside the Data on Insider Threats: What 1,000 Real Cases Reveal About Hidden Risk
item.description: Security analyst Michael Robinson spent 14 months mining thousands of legal filings to uncover who malicious insiders really are, how they operate, and why traditional detection models keep missing them.
item.dc:creator: Joan Goodchild

item.title: From Chef to CISO: An Empathy-First Approach to Cybersecurity Leadership
item.description: Myke Lyons, CISO at data-processing SaaS company Cribl, shares how he cooked up an unconventional journey from culinary school to cybersecurity leadership.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek

item.title: The AI Trust Paradox: Why Security Teams Fear Automated Remediation
item.description: Security teams invest in AI for automated remediation but hesitate to trust it fully due to fears of unintended consequences and lack of transparency.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Shields

item.title: YouTube Ghost Network Utilizes Spooky Tactics to Target Users
item.description: The malware operation uses compromised accounts and bot networks to distribute infostealers and has tripled its output in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek

item.title: Oracle EBS Attack Victims May Be More Numerous Than Expected
item.description: Numerous organizations have been attacked via Oracle EBS zero-day CVE-2025-61882, and evidence suggests more like Schneider Electric could be on that list.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: New TEE.Fail Side-Channel Attack Extracts Secrets from Intel and AMD DDR5 Secure Enclaves
item.description: A group of academic researchers from Georgia Tech, Purdue University, and Synkhronix have developed a side-channel attack called TEE.Fail that allows for the extraction of secrets from the trusted execution environment (TEE) in a computer's main processor, including Intel's Software Guard eXtensions (SGX) and Trust Domain Extensions (TDX) and AMD's Secure Encrypted Virtualization with Secure
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New Android Trojan 'Herodotus' Outsmarts Anti-Fraud Systems by Typing Like a Human
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new Android banking trojan called Herodotus that has been observed in active campaigns targeting Italy and Brazil to conduct device takeover (DTO) attacks. "Herodotus is designed to perform device takeover while making first attempts to mimic human behaviour and bypass behaviour biometrics detection," ThreatFabric said in a report shared with
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Expose GhostCall and GhostHire: BlueNoroff's New Malware Chains
item.description: Threat actors tied to North Korea have been observed targeting the Web3 and blockchain sectors as part of twin campaigns tracked as GhostCall and GhostHire. According to Kaspersky, the campaigns are part of a broader operation called SnatchCrypto that has been underway since at least 2017. The activity is attributed to a Lazarus Group sub-cluster called BlueNoroff, which is also known as APT38,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: North Korea's BlueNoroff Expands Scope of Crypto Heists
item.description: Two campaigns targeting fintech execs and Web3 developers show the APT going cross-platform in financially motivated campaigns that use fake business collaboration and job recruitment lures.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Why Early Threat Detection Is a Must for Long-Term Business Growth
item.description: In cybersecurity, speed isn’t just a win — it’s a multiplier. The faster you learn about emerging threats, the faster you adapt your defenses, the less damage you suffer, and the more confidently your business keeps scaling. Early threat detection isn’t about preventing a breach someday: it’s about protecting the revenue you’re supposed to earn every day. Companies that treat cybersecurity as a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Is Your Google Workspace as Secure as You Think it is?
item.description: The New Reality for Lean Security Teams If you’re the first security or IT hire at a fast-growing startup, you’ve likely inherited a mandate that’s both simple and maddeningly complex: secure the business without slowing it down. Most organizations using Google Workspace start with an environment built for collaboration, not resilience. Shared drives, permissive settings, and constant
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Chrome Zero-Day Exploited to Deliver Italian Memento Labs' LeetAgent Spyware
item.description: The zero-day exploitation of a now-patched security flaw in Google Chrome led to the distribution of an espionage-related tool from Italian information technology and services provider Memento Labs, according to new findings from Kaspersky. The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-2783 (CVSS score: 8.3), a case of sandbox escape which the company disclosed in March 2025 as having come under
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: SideWinder Adopts New ClickOnce-Based Attack Chain Targeting South Asian Diplomats
item.description: A European embassy located in the Indian capital of New Delhi, as well as multiple organizations in Sri Lanka, Pakistan, and Bangladesh, have emerged as the target of a new campaign orchestrated by a threat actor known as SideWinder in September 2025. The activity "reveals a notable evolution in SideWinder's TTPs, particularly the adoption of a novel PDF and ClickOnce-based infection chain, in
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: Explore the top features of attack surface visibility software, why it matters for cybersecurity, and how to choose the right tool for your organization.

item.description: <p>Severe bugs in Dell Storage Manager let hackers bypass authentication and gain remote access. item.description: While investigating the cyberattacks, researchers uncovered a new spyware product from Memento Labs, the successor to the infamous Hacking Team.

item.title: CISOs Finally Get a Seat at the Board's Table — But There's a Catch
item.description: AI's explosive growth has lifted cybersecurity to the top of the board's agenda. Here's how CISOs can seize the moment, according to Diana Kelley.

item.description: Atroposia, a new RAT malware, offers low-level cybercriminal affiliates the ability to utilize sophisticated stealth and persistence capabilities.

item.description: Social media platform X is urging users who have enrolled for two-factor authentication (2FA) using passkeys and hardware security keys like Yubikeys to re-enroll their key to ensure continued access to the service. item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a new vulnerability in OpenAI's ChatGPT Atlas web browser that could allow malicious actors to inject nefarious instructions into the artificial intelligence (AI)-powered assistant's memory and run arbitrary code. "This exploit can allow attackers to infect systems with malicious code, grant themselves access privileges, or deploy malware," LayerX
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: WSUS Exploited, LockBit 5.0 Returns, Telegram Backdoor, F5 Breach Widens
item.description: Security, trust, and stability — once the pillars of our digital world — are now the tools attackers turn against us. From stolen accounts to fake job offers, cybercriminals keep finding new ways to exploit both system flaws and human behavior. Each new breach proves a harsh truth: in cybersecurity, feeling safe can be far more dangerous than being alert. Here’s how that false sense of security
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: The ransomware group known as Qilin (aka Agenda, Gold Feather, and Water Galura) has claimed more than 40 victims every month since the start of 2025, barring January, with the number of postings on its data leak site touching a high of 100 cases in June. The development comes as the ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation has emerged as one of the most active ransomware groups, accounting for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ChatGPT Atlas Browser Can Be Tricked by Fake URLs into Executing Hidden Commands
item.description: The newly released OpenAI ChatGPT Atlas web browser has been found to be susceptible to a prompt injection attack where its omnibox can be jailbroken by disguising a malicious prompt as a seemingly harmless URL to visit. "The omnibox (combined address/search bar) interprets input either as a URL to navigate to, or as a natural-language command to the agent," NeuralTrust said in a report
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.description: This guide explains why simply resetting a password is a dangerously flawed response and outlines a new, identity-centric defense framework.

item.title: Microsoft Issues Emergency Patch for Critical Windows Server Bug
item.description: Microsoft initially fixed CVE-2025-59287 in the WSUS update mechanism in the October 2025 Patch Tuesday release, but the company has now issued a second, out-of-band update for the flaw, which is under attack in the wild.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Smishing Triad Linked to 194,000 Malicious Domains in Global Phishing Operation
item.description: The threat actors behind a large-scale, ongoing smishing campaign have been attributed to more than 194,000 malicious domains since January 1, 2024, targeting a broad range of services across the world, according to new findings from Palo Alto Networks Unit 42. "Although these domains are registered through a Hong Kong-based registrar and use Chinese nameservers, the attack infrastructure is
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: How CISA Layoffs Weaken Civilian Cyber Defense
item.description: Cyber teams need to get to work backfilling diminishing federal resources, according to Alexander Garcia-Tobar, who shares clear steps on a path forward for protecting enterprises with less CISA help.
item.dc:creator: Alexander García-Tobar

item.title: Newly Patched Critical Microsoft WSUS Flaw Comes Under Active Exploitation
item.description: Microsoft on Thursday released out-of-band security updates to patch a&nbsp;critical-severity Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) vulnerability with a proof-of-concept (Poc) exploit publicly available and has come under active exploitation in the wild. The vulnerability in question is CVE-2025-59287 (CVSS score: 9.8), a remote code execution flaw in WSUS that was originally fixed by the tech
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Shutdown Sparks 85% Increase in US Government Cyberattacks
item.description: Attackers are pouncing on financially strapped US government agencies and furloughed employees. And the effects of this period might be felt for a long time hereafter.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: APT36 Targets Indian Government with Golang-Based DeskRAT Malware Campaign
item.description: A Pakistan-nexus threat actor has been observed targeting Indian government entities as part of spear-phishing attacks designed to deliver a Golang-based malware known as DeskRAT. The activity, observed in August and September 2025 by Sekoia, has been attributed to Transparent Tribe (aka APT36), a state-sponsored hacking group known to be active since at least 2013. It also builds upon a prior
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Part Four of The Kryptos Sculpture
item.description: <p>Two people <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/16/science/kryptos-cia-solution-sanborn-auction.html">found the solution</a>. They used the power of research, not cryptanalysis, finding clues amongst the Sanborn papers at the Smithsonian&#8217;s Archives of American Art.</p> <p>This comes as an awkward time, as Sanborn is <a href="https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2025/08/jim-sanborn-is-auctioning-off-the-solution-to-part-four-of-the-kryptos-sculpture.html">auctioning off</a> the solution. There were legal threats&#8212;I don&#8217;t understand their basis&#8212;and the solvers are not publishing their solution.</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: The Cybersecurity Perception Gap: Why Executives and Practitioners See Risk Differently
item.description: Does your organization suffer from a cybersecurity perception gap? Findings from the&nbsp;Bitdefender 2025 Cybersecurity Assessment suggest the answer is probably “yes” — and many leaders may not even realize it. This disconnect matters. Small differences in perception today can evolve into major blind spots tomorrow. After all, perception influences what organizations prioritize, where they
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 3,000 YouTube Videos Exposed as Malware Traps in Massive Ghost Network Operation
item.description: A malicious network of YouTube accounts has been observed publishing and promoting videos that lead to malware downloads, essentially abusing the popularity and trust associated with the video hosting platform for propagating malicious payloads. Active since 2021, the network has published more than 3,000 malicious videos to date, with the volume of such videos tripling since the start of the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Self-Spreading 'GlassWorm' Infects VS Code Extensions in Widespread Supply Chain Attack
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a self-propagating worm that spreads via Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extensions on the Open VSX Registry and the Microsoft Extension Marketplace, underscoring how developers have become a prime target for attacks. The sophisticated threat, codenamed GlassWorm by Koi Security, is the second such supply chain attack to hit the DevOps space within a span
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: What is Attack Surface Management? Tools and Best Practices | UpGuard
item.description: This is a complete overview of attack surface management. Learn how attack surface management can keep your organization secure in this in-depth post.

item.title: Threat Monitoring for Superannuation Security | UpGuard
item.description: Attackers breached superannuation customer accounts with stolen credentials. We look at one way to detect compromised accounts sooner.
